section.heading: Purpose and Scope.
section.text: This chapter describes the procedures of the Administration to establish a child support obligation by means of an affidavit of support. The chapter also describes the process for rescinding an executed affidavit of support.

para.text: In this chapter, the following terms have the meanings indicated.
Terms Defined.
"Child support order" has the meaning stated in Family Law Article, §10-1A-01, Annotated Code of Maryland.
"Date of execution" means:
The date that all parties and the Administration have signed the affidavit of support form; or
If a party or the Administration signs the affidavit of support on a date that is different from the date the other party or the Administration has signed, then the latest of the dates.
"Executed affidavit of support" means an affidavit of support form that all parties and the Administration have signed.

"On the record" means a document attached to the affidavit of support which delineates the reasons for deviating from child support guidelines pursuant to Family Law Article, Title 12, Subtitle 2, Annotated Code of Maryland.
"Party" has the meaning stated in Family Law Article, §10-1A-01, Annotated Code of Maryland.
"Support conference" means a conference conducted by the Administration to provide an opportunity to the parties to voluntarily agree to the provisions of a support obligation.

section.heading: Affidavit of Support to Establish a Support Obligation.

para.text: The Administration may initiate action to establish a child support obligation pursuant to Family Law Article, Title 10, Subtitle 1A, Annotated Code of Maryland, if:
A party is receiving child support services under Title IV, Part D, of the Social Security Act;
Paternity of the child has been established;
A support conference, as specified in §B of this regulation, has been conducted; and
The support conference resulted in an agreement by the parties.
Support Conference. Before the execution of an affidavit of support, the Administration shall provide notice to the parties to attend the support conference. The notice shall:
Specify the date, time, and location of the support conference;
Advise the parties of the purpose of the support conference;
Specify the documentation the parties are required to provide; and
Be provided to the parties at least 30 days before the date on which the support conference will be held.
Support Obligation Amount.
The Administration shall compute the child support obligation pursuant to Family Law Article, Title 12, Subtitle 2, Annotated Code of Maryland.

The Administration may consider the factors stated in Family Law Article, §12-202, Annotated Code of Maryland, to determine if application of the guidelines would be unjust or inappropriate in a particular case.

Upon determining that application of the guidelines is unjust or inappropriate in a particular case, the Administration shall make a written finding on the record. The Administration's finding shall state:
The amount of child support that would have been required under the guidelines;
How the affidavit of support varies from the guidelines;
How the finding serves the best interest of the child; and
In cases in which items of value are conveyed instead of a portion of the support presumed under the guidelines, the estimated value of the items conveyed.
Executing an Affidavit of Support.
An affidavit of support shall be on a standardized form developed by the Administration.
The completed affidavit of support form shall contain:
Those statements provided for in Family Law Article, §10-1A-02(c), Annotated Code of Maryland; and
Any other information considered appropriate by the Administration.
Before completing an affidavit of support form, the Administration shall inform the parties, orally and in writing, of:
The legal consequences of executing the affidavit; and
The right to seek legal counsel.
The Administration shall provide each party with a copy of the executed affidavit of support.

Following the 60-day rescission period specified in Regulation .04A of this chapter, the Administration shall file the affidavit of support with the clerk of a circuit court within 30 days following the recission period for the court's approval.
A party may rescind the affidavit of support within 60 days after execution.
To be effective, the request for rescission shall be:
In writing, on a standardized form developed by the Administration;
Signed and dated before a notary public; and
Received by the Administration within 60 days from the date of execution.
When an affidavit of support is properly rescinded:
The obligation for ongoing support terminates;
Any arrears accrued after the affidavit of support was executed remain owed to the obligee until paid; and
Any support amount paid and disbursed to the custodial parent after the affidavit of support was executed, is owed to the custodial parent and is not subject to a refund to the noncustodial parent.

section.heading: Enforcement of an Affidavit of Support.

para.text: The Administration shall enforce the provisions of the affidavit of support and collect the support obligation, including arrearages, from the date of execution.

The affidavit of support shall be regarded in the same manner as a child support order issued by a court, with all the same enforcement remedies, including contempt of court, that are available to a support order issued by a tribunal.

Pursuant to Family Law Article, §10-1A-03, Annotated Code of Maryland, if any party to the affidavit of support presents evidence to the Administration of a material change in circumstances since entry of the last child support order, the parties may execute a subsequent affidavit of support.
If there is a preexisting child support order, the subsequently executed affidavit of support supersedes the order until overruled by a tribunal.
